chunks.en: Saw many motorcycles daring to go 150 km/h on the highway

This year, driving to my mother-in-law's place, I saw many motorcycles on the highway. Their speed was probably around 150 km/h. It's the first time I've seen riders daring to drive like that on the highway. I don't know what to say, are they showing off their skills or do they think their lives are too long?
Reading some of the replies in this thread, you'll see that just respect and offer blessings, no need to worry about other people's lives.
Mind your own business
I don't care if the rider is in danger, just don't crash into my car.
Drop the savior complex, respect other people's fate.
They will have their destined good fortune, don't worry about it.
Every time the topic of speeding on the highway comes up, some experienced drivers treat illegal behavior as their qualification, regardless of whether they have one, two, three... or ten wheels.

The new year just passed, I wish all law-abiding drivers can stay away from these land-based cruise missiles, and I also wish those missiles can find a quiet place to blow themselves up and contribute to reducing the population burden in our country.
Some people dare to drive drunk, can't understand someone saying they are going 150?

@Midnight The danger is that cars wouldn't expect a motorcycle speeding at 150+ km/h overtaking between lanes while they are driving at 130 km/h, and it might even be completely in the right-side blind spot.
Fortunately, high displacement motorcycles have loud engine sounds.
These vehicles are speeding and breaking the law, no question about it.

The reality is that avoiding the mobile roadblocks that only fill up one tank of gas per year and only get on the highway during free toll periods might actually be safer for these motorcycle riders than speeding. ğŸ¤¨
The problem is that these people's speeding will affect the life and property safety of others.
@wtks1 Respect and blessings? I don't care if they die, I care about them harming other people on the road.
150 is actually okay for motorcycles with 600cc or more. In foreign countries, I see 200+ all the time, that's crazy.
I don't quite understand where the malice towards the motorcycle group comes from. I drive and ride myself. If you're talking about idiots, which group doesn't have them?
It's not necessarily motorcycles causing noise on the streets, four-wheeled sports cars do the same.

As for highways prohibiting motorcycles, in fact, the motorcycle bans in many cities themselves are illegal, with no regulatory documents or expired documents, or have not passed the legislative review of the local people's congress.
Motorcycles are allowed on the highway in many cities, but the traffic law stipulates that motorcycles are only allowed to travel at 80 km/h on the highway, so this 150 is definitely speeding.
Leaving aside the speed limit, riding slowly on the highway is more dangerous for motorcycles; it's safer to stay ahead of the traffic flow.

Finally, let me state that although the regulation prohibiting motorcycles from entering the highway is itself illegal, the legally limited speed of 80 km/h and my understanding of the safety of motorcycles on the highway are mutually exclusive, so I don't ride a motorcycle on the highway.
@Eddiegaao I am indeed a person who is often ridiculously late, but at least I know it's wrong, and I'm the type who knows it's wrong but doesn't change.
But at least I wouldn't say that I'm never more than '20%' late to praise my precise time management.
The reason I don't think I'm being hypocritical is that I think being 1 minute late is still being late, and speeding 1 km/h is still speeding, and I wouldn't be proud of it.
Cars, trucks, and motorcycles all speed, just don't speed yourself.
What kind of vehicle? 150 is not slow, how did you estimate it?
For some motorcycles, 150km/h is the maximum speed in first gear.
Respect and blessings
Drop... respect...
Are there really motorcycles on the highway?
